awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to continue the New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology (NMT) participation in the CyberCorps®: Scholarship for Service (SFS) program to prepare highly-qualified Cybersecurity professionals for entry into the government workforce. NMT is a Hispanic Serving Institution, designated as a Center of Academic Excellence in Information Assurance Education and Research by the National Security Agency, and meeting the criteria for multiple training standards (CNSS 4011, 4012, 4013E and 4016E.) To date, the program has graduated 47 CyberCorps® SFS students including four Native Americans, three Hispanics, one Asian American, and nine women. This project will provide a multi-disciplinary, integrated education, research, and training to additional 13 CyberCorps® SFS scholars. The project's objective is to prepare CyberCorps® SFS scholars to become leaders in civil service, not merely practitioners, in the field of Cybersecurity. The NSF's CyberCorps® SFS program funds projects that address Cybersecurity education and workforce development. The Scholarship Track provides funding to award scholarships to students in Cybersecurity. In return for their scholarships, recipients will work after graduation for a Federal, State, Local, or Tribal Government organization in a position related to Cybersecurity for a period equal to the length of the scholarship. The Capacity Track seeks innovative proposals leading to an increase in the ability of the United States higher education enterprise to produce Cybersecurity professionals. 

The curriculum includes practical, hands-on applications of Cybersecurity coordinated between the Computer Science and Engineering (CSE) Department, the Information Technology (IT) Program, the Institute for Complex Additive Systems Analysis (ICASA), and other academic departments. By integrating research projects in advanced courses, the project enhances problem solving and develops CyberCorps® SFS scholars who are subject matter experts in the area of their selected focus. The underlying curriculum principle is to integrate Cybersecurity content in every core CSE and IT course from algorithms and architecture to software engineering. For example, in the software engineering course, students learn best practices on software design and verification for security; in the compiler writing course, students learn the security implications of design decisions in compilers; and during their compiler implementation project, they implement a security optimization such as buffer overflow protection. This integration of Cybersecurity concepts impacts all of the students who take the CSE or IT courses.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology

por.por_cntn:
CyberCorp Cadre, NSF award 1303051 

The New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology (NMT) CyberCorp Cadre project's primary purpose was to educate and train 13 CyberCorp Scholarship for Service students and prepare them for then place them into the government workforce. By the end of the grant, 17 students had been fully (13) or partially (4) supported. Of the 17 students, two are female, four are Hispanic and one is Native American. Students were provided a multidisciplinary, integrated education, research, professional development, and training program. New courses developed and taught in conjunction with this program include Foundations of Information Security, Red/Blue Cybersecurity Exploration, Secure Systems Administration, Hardware-based Network Security, Computer Security Incident Response and Digital Forensics, Blockchain and Cryptocurrencies, and Reverse Engineering. The training aspects of the program included professional development of skills such as presentations to government leadership, documenting business cases for cybersecurity, and performing cybersecurity audits. For example, students were trained on how to carry out cybersecurity audits including social engineering, threat modeling, network mapping, network security testing, firewall testing, security remediation planning, and audit reporting including prioritization of threats and associated mitigation based on severity and threat model. Scholars then went on to practice these skills in municipalities and schools across New Mexico, which resulted in improving the security of the state's infrastructure and the awareness of threats, vulnerabilities, mitigations, and best practices by local community governments. Equally importantly, these security audit experiences left scholars better prepared to have positive impacts on their government agencies upon arrival. Graduates of the CyberCorp Cadre program have been prepared to become cybersecurity leaders in civil service, not merely practitioners. Finally, students from our Scholarship for Service Program continue to typically remain in their government positions much longer than they are required to due to the care with which student and agency matching is done. Our longest placement has been with his agency for seventeen years and all but one of the students placed during this grant are still with their agencies.

Research related to, but not necessarily funded by, this grant has resulted in at least 9 refereed conference or journal publications and one US patent. This does not include additional research related to cybersecurity across other disciplines. Several disciplines are now collaborating on research and education related to cybersecurity: Computer Science and Engineering, Electrical Engineering, Communications, Psychology, Sociology, Mechanical Engineering, and Materials Engineering. This collaboration extends the impact of this program well beyond the original proposal.  

The Scholarship for Service program and the associated Centers of Academic Excellence leadership conference resulted in the development of a proposal for a Cybersecurity Education Center (CEC) at NMT as well as the following cybersecurity graduate programs: Graduate Certificate in Cybersecurity, Professional Master of Transdisciplinary Cybersecurity, Master of Science in Transdisciplinary Cybersecurity, and Doctor of Philosophy in Transdisciplinary Cybersecurity. New courses developed for the Transdisciplinary Cybersecurity graduate programs include Data Science for Cybersecurity, Psychology of Cybersecurity, Cybersecurity Ethics and Law, Cybersecurity Policy, Formal Methods for Cybersecurity Policy, Cyber Physical System Security, Cybersecurity Risk Analysis and Management. In addition, the CEC has funded the development of infrastructure and a Cybersecurity Fundamentals course for the Master of Science for Teachers program to widely disseminate, vai K12 teachers, cybersecurity basics and best practices as well as opportunities for students to become cybersecurity professionals. The PI (Lorie M. Liebrock) is the Director of NMT's CEC, as well as of the New Mexico Cybersecurity Center of Excellence (NMCCoE). Both centers have base funding provided by the State of New Mexico with additional funding coming from grants and contracts. These centers are leading the development of a state-wide CyberReadyNM program to enhance education, research, economic development, and awareness in cybersecurity for the state of New Mexico and the nation. The Cybersecurity Centers also host outreach events to improve awareness of cybersecurity threats, mitigations, best practices, and career opportunities to diverse audiences from K12 students to senior citizens.

The CyberCorp Cadre's successful participation in the National Security Agency's (NSA) Codebreaker Challenge (CBC) led to the development of a Codebreaker Challenge Expansion project that is working to grow participation of students across the nation. Further, the online Community of Practice (CoP) developed for CBC provides educational materials, community engagement, and assistance for participants as well as helping to maintain the ethical standards expected by our community through a (primarily) self-regulating set of community commitments to ethical and positive behavior. The EULA for the CoP was developed by the Scholarship for Service cohort and approved by NSA for use in both the CBC and CoP.

In summary, the CyberCorp Cadre project has not only met the proposed goal of preparing and placing 13 excellent Scholars in approved government positions, but also had substantial impacts on NMT and the State of New Mexico by inspiring major development and collaboration in cybersecurity.  

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2021
Modified by: Lorie M Liebrock
